content: The Land Reinvestment Act may be cited as the official title. It imposes limitations on the use of funds from the Land and Water Conservation Fund. The Land and Water Conservation Fund Act of 1965 is amended to prioritize maintenance over acquisition in various sections. The Land and Water Conservation Fund Act of 1965 is amended to prioritize maintenance over acquisition in wilderness areas of the National Forest System and federal lands acquired for endangered species and threatened species under various acts. The head of each covered landholding agency must reduce backlogged maintenance by 20% within 5 fiscal years of the enactment of the Act, and continue to reduce maintenance backlog in subsequent 5-year periods. The Act requires covered landholding agencies to reduce backlogged maintenance by 20% within 5 fiscal years, and address any additional maintenance backlog that arises after the enactment of the Act. The Act mandates covered landholding agencies to reduce backlogged maintenance by 20% within 5 fiscal years and address any additional backlog that arises after the Act's enactment. The covered landholding agencies must publish reports documenting progress in reducing backlogged maintenance, including the dollar value of reduction achieved in a 5-fiscal-year period, compliance with required reductions, and any shortfall in reduction amount. The covered landholding agencies must publish reports detailing construction, deferred maintenance, and regular maintenance projects needed to reduce backlogged maintenance as required by section 3. The reports must also include a plan for carrying out these projects over the next 5 fiscal years. The first report must be published and submitted within 30 days after the end of the first 5-fiscal-year period following the enactment of the Act, with subsequent reports to follow. The covered landholding agencies must prioritize lands for maintenance based on program success and submit final reports to Congress once all backlogged maintenance is completed. The covered landholding agencies prioritize lands for maintenance based on program success and submit final reports to Congress once all backlogged maintenance is completed. This includes a system of regular maintenance and a prioritized list of capital improvement projects for such lands. SEC. 5 of the Act requires covered landholding agencies to prioritize Federal lands based on their importance to agency programs. Within 4 years of the Act's enactment, a report must be submitted to Congress ranking these lands from highest to lowest priority. SEC. 6 provides definitions for key terms used in the Act. The term "backlogged maintenance" in the Act refers to the total dollar value of incomplete regular maintenance, deferred maintenance, and capital improvements on lands under covered landholding agencies. As of the enactment date, it is $354,000,000 for Bureau of Land Management lands and $1,500,000,000 for United States Fish and Wildlife Service lands. The covered landholding agencies, including the Bureau of Land Management, United States Fish and Wildlife Service, Forest Service, and National Park Service, have allocated funds for maintenance of their lands. Maintenance includes upkeep, capital improvements, and development of real property.
